Hilbert spaces

Let H\mathcal{H}H be the space of holomorphic functions fff on the unit disc D={z∈C∣∣z∣<1}\D = \set{z \in \C \mid \abs{z} < 1}D={z∈C∣∣z∣<1} such that

∫D∣f(z)∣2 dA(z)<∞.\int_\D \abs{f\p{z}}^2 \,\diff{A}\p{z} < \infty.∫D​∣f(z)∣2dA(z)<∞.

Here integration is with respect to Lebesgue measure AAA on D\DD. The vector space H\mathcal{H}H is a Hilbert space if equipped with the inner product

⟨f,g⟩=∫Df(z)g(z)‾ dA(z)\inner{f, g} = \int_\D f\p{z} \conj{g\p{z}} \,\diff{A}\p{z}⟨f,g⟩=∫D​f(z)g(z)​dA(z)

for f,g∈Hf, g \in \mathcal{H}f,g∈H. Fix z0∈Dz_0 \in \Dz0​∈D and define Lz0(f)=f(z0)L_{z_0}\p{f} = f\p{z_0}Lz0​​(f)=f(z0​) for f∈Hf \in \mathcal{H}f∈H.

  1. Show that Lz0 ⁣:H→C\func{L_{z_0}}{\mathcal{H}}{\C}Lz0​​:H→C is a bounded linear functional on H\mathcal{H}H.

  2. Find an explicit function gz0∈Hg_{z_0} \in \mathcal{H}gz0​​∈H such that

    Lz0(f)=f(z0)=⟨f,gz0⟩L_{z_0}\p{f} = f\p{z_0} = \inner{f, g_{z_0}}Lz0​​(f)=f(z0​)=⟨f,gz0​​⟩

    for all f∈Hf \in \mathcal{H}f∈H.
Solution.

  1. Let δ=12d(z0,Dc)\delta = \frac{1}{2}d\p{z_0, \D^\comp}δ=21​d(z0​,Dc) so that B(z0,δ)‾⊆D\cl{B\p{z_0, \delta}} \subseteq \DB(z0​,δ)​⊆D. Then by the mean value property and Cauchy-Schwarz,

    ∣f(z0)∣≤1πδ2∬B(z0,δ)∣f(z)∣ dA(z)≤m(D)1/2πδ2∥f∥L2,\abs{f\p{z_0}} \leq \frac{1}{\pi\delta^2} \iint_{B\p{z_0,\delta}} \abs{f\p{z}} \,\diff{A}\p{z} \leq \frac{m\p{\D}^{1/2}}{\pi\delta^2} \norm{f}_{L^2},∣f(z0​)∣≤πδ21​∬B(z0​,δ)​∣f(z)∣dA(z)≤πδ2m(D)1/2​∥f∥L2​,

    so Lz0L_{z_0}Lz0​​ is a bounded linear operator.

  2. Recall that

    f(z0)=1π∫Df(z)(1−z‾z0)2 dA(z).f\p{z_0} = \frac{1}{\pi} \int_\D \frac{f\p{z}}{\p{1 - \conj{z}z_0}^2} \,\diff{A}\p{z}.f(z0​)=π1​∫D​(1−zz0​)2f(z)​dA(z).

    From this, we immediately see that g(z)=1(1−zz0‾)2g\p{z} = \frac{1}{\p{1 - z\conj{z_0}}^2}g(z)=(1−zz0​​)21​ represents Lz0L_{z_0}Lz0​​: clearly ggg is holomorphic, and it is bounded on D\DD since its only pole is at z0∣z0∣2\frac{z_0}{\abs{z_0}^2}∣z0​∣2z0​​ which is outside D\DD. To complete the proof, it remains to prove this formula.

    Write

    f(z)=∑n=0∞anznand1(1−z‾z0)2=∑n=0∞(n+1)(z‾z0)n.f\p{z} = \sum_{n=0}^\infty a_nz^n \quad\text{and}\quad \frac{1}{\p{1 - \conj{z}z_0}^2} = \sum_{n=0}^\infty \p{n + 1}\p{\conj{z}z_0}^n.f(z)=n=0∑∞​an​znand(1−zz0​)21​=n=0∑∞​(n+1)(zz0​)n.

    Observe also that if n≠mn \neq mn=m,

    ∫Dznz‾m dA(z)=∫01∫02πrn+m+1einθe−imθdθ dr=0.\int_\D z^n \conj{z}^m \,\diff{A}\p{z} = \int_0^1 \int_0^{2\pi} r^{n+m+1} e^{in\theta} e^{-im\theta} \diff\theta \,\diff{r} = 0.∫D​znzmdA(z)=∫01​∫02π​rn+m+1einθe−imθdθdr=0.

    If n=mn = mn=m, then

    ∫Dznz‾m dA(z)=πn+1.\int_\D z^n \conj{z}^m \,\diff{A}\p{z} = \frac{\pi}{n + 1}.∫D​znzmdA(z)=n+1π​.

    Hence, because all series converge locally uniformly, we have

    1π∫Df(z)1−z‾z0 dA(z)=1π∫D(∑n=0∞anzn)(∑m=0∞(m+1)(z‾z0)m) dA(z)=1π∑n=0∞∑m=0∞anz0m(m+1)∫Dznz‾m dA(z)=1π∑n=0∞anz0n(n+1)πn+1=∑n=0∞anz0n=f(z0),\begin{aligned} \frac{1}{\pi} \int_\D \frac{f\p{z}}{1 - \conj{z}z_0} \,\diff{A}\p{z} &= \frac{1}{\pi} \int_\D \p{\sum_{n=0}^\infty a_nz^n} \p{\sum_{m=0}^\infty \p{m+1}\p{\conj{z}z_0}^m} \,\diff{A}\p{z} \\ &= \frac{1}{\pi} \sum_{n=0}^\infty \sum_{m=0}^\infty a_nz_0^m\p{m + 1} \int_\D z^n\conj{z}^m \,\diff{A}\p{z} \\ &= \frac{1}{\pi} \sum_{n=0}^\infty a_nz_0^n\p{n + 1} \frac{\pi}{n + 1} \\ &= \sum_{n=0}^\infty a_n z_0^n \\ &= f\p{z_0}, \end{aligned}π1​∫D​1−zz0​f(z)​dA(z)​=π1​∫D​(n=0∑∞​an​zn)(m=0∑∞​(m+1)(zz0​)m)dA(z)=π1​n=0∑∞​m=0∑∞​an​z0m​(m+1)∫D​znzmdA(z)=π1​n=0∑∞​an​z0n​(n+1)n+1π​=n=0∑∞​an​z0n​=f(z0​),​

    which completes the proof.
